entry.title: Re: Add Material Description and Partner Activity Type Fi...
entry.content:
Hello @Alendro17 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Data Source Extensions, Key User Extensibility, Market Segment - Plan/Actuals, Projects - Plan/Actual

I would also recommend reading through Blogs: Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud – Data Source Extensions – Part 1 & Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud – Data Source Extensions – Part 2

In summary, please note that the clean-core principle in the public cloud ensures the system provide the predefined process. Which explains why you face some of those issues.

Below are simplified reasons and what you should do.

Answer to Issue 1: The Order ID description is not wrong; the market segment cube does not store material description for orders. You can display it by creating a custom CDS join and build a custom analytical query.

Answer to Issue 2: The Partner Activity Type is missing because the Market Segment cubes does not contain this field. You can only add it that when you use a custom CDS extension and custom query.

Answer to Issue 3: The reason it does not appear is because you did not enable analytics. You should enable the Data Source Extension in Custom Fields app and then create a custom analytical query.

 

Here is step-by-step guide on how to achieve adding the custom fields.

First is to open you Custom Fields

Then select your field, enable Analytics: Data Source (Here you should enable for Analytics, OData, UI), then save and publish.

Next you should extend Analytical Cube using Custom Analytical Queries. Click Create

For the primary Data Source, use: I_ENGMNTPROJACTLPLANCUBE.

Then add your custom fields.

Thereafter, create your custom report. You can give as an example the name Z_PROJECT_PLAN_ACTUAL. Then add your fields, publish it and add it to Fiori catalog.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Use Datastore to avoid too many duplicate MPL attachments in exception retries
entry.content:
Hi,

This is a clever way to avoid storing the same payload multiple times. Thank you for this insight!

However, I'm curious—when would unlimited or very high retry limits (such as 100 attempts) be applicable? In my experience, retrying more than a few times doesn't make sense. Beyond that, it's better to route undelivered messages to a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) and reduce the retry frequency.

On the other hand, this approach introduces another challenge: after a few hours, or especially days, your persisted data (particularly if it originates from data events) may already be obsolete. Delivering stale data to the target system could create discrepancies between the source and target. One solution might be to refresh the data via an API call when processing a retry.

I'd appreciate any thoughts or observations you might have on this!

BR

Mateusz

entry.title: Re: API integration with SAP Business One
entry.content:
To integrate an AI Chatbot system with SAP Business One On-Premises using SAP B1 API to access information like Accounts Payable and Accounts Receivable, you will require an appropriate SAP Business One license for integration purposes. Specifically, an "Indirect Access" license is typically needed for external applications or third-party systems that access SAP Business One data via APIs or external programs without using the regular SAP Business One user interface. This license enables the data exchange from your chatbot system to SAP Business One through the API.

The Indirect Access license is distinct from the standard user licenses (such as Professional, Limited, or Starter Package users) and caters to background data integrations such as middleware or custom applications reading and writing data to SAP Business One. Without this license, using SAP Business One API for your chatbot can violate SAP licensing terms.

If you wish to proceed, it’s recommended to coordinate with your SAP partner or SAP account representative to obtain and correctly license the Indirect Access for your chatbot integration project to ensure compliance.

This applies to SAP Business One On-Premises installations and aligns with SAP’s current licensing guidance for API and external system access to business data.

entry.title: How to Assign Item Category to Material While Syncing to SAP CPQ – And Why It Matters
entry.content:
When integrating SAP CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) with SAP S/4HANA or ERP, ECC, one critical step often overlooked is assigning the Item Category to materials during synchronization. This seemingly small detail plays a major role in ensuring smooth downstream processes like Sales Orders, Solution Quotations, and Solution Orders.

What is an Item Category ?

An Item Category in SAP determines how a material behaves in a document. It controls:

  • Whether the item is relevant for pricing.
  • If it requires a delivery or billing.
  • Whether it’s a service, a configurable product, or a standard material.
  • How it integrates with BOMs or solution components.

Reference Article/Blog explaining Item Categeory & group : Link

In short, the Item Category defines the business logic for the material in transactional documents.

Why Assign Item Category During Sync to SAP CPQ?

When materials are synced from SAP ERP to SAP CPQ, they carry essential attributes like material number, description, and pricing conditions. However, without the correct Item Category, CPQ cannot:

  • Determine if the material is a physical product, service, or text item.
  • Apply correct pricing and tax rules.
  • Generate accurate solution structures for complex configurations.

This impacts the integration when below are created:

  • Sales Orders: Applies for all ERP, S/4 HANA Public & Private Cloud
  • Solution Quotations: S/4 HANA Private Cloud or On-prem versions (Sales, Service & Subscription)
  • Solution Orders: S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (Sales, Service & Subscription)

Integration with SAP CPQ for Material Replication

SAP CPQ provides Product RestAPI to update itemcategorygroup for Materials..

Technical Note: Updating Item Category in SAP CPQ

SAP CPQ provides a Product REST API that allows you to update the itemCategory field for products. This is useful when you need to dynamically adjust item categories after initial synchronization or based on business rules.

  • Field: itemCategory
  • Purpose: Stores the ERP item category value or a mapped equivalent.
  • Usage: Can be updated via REST API calls for products in CPQ.

Integration Considerations

The standard SAP CPQ–SAP ERP/S4 HANA integration iFlow currently uses SOAP XML for material synchronization. This means:

  • Item category values from ERP cannot be included in the SOAP payload. (Help Doc)
  • If additional updates are needed post-sync, you can leverage the REST API for CPQ to patch the itemCategory field.

Conclusion:
Assigning the right Item Category during material sync to SAP CPQ is not just a technical step—it’s a business-critical process that ensures seamless integration, accurate pricing, and smooth execution of sales and solution orders.

entry.title: Re: VOFM – Custom Routine for Packaging Instruction Deter...
entry.content:
Dear @vicentejarque,

No, in Public Cloud you can’t develop your own VOFM-style condition/formula routines for packing/packaging instruction determination.

What is supported in Public cloud is custom logic only where SAP has released a Cloud Badi implemented via the Custom Logic extensibility framework. SAP states this explicitly for VOFM successors for example in pricing custom logic is possible only for the delivered Cloud Badi, classic VOFM routines are an on-premise concept

Correct approach in Public Cloud:

1. Stay within standard condition technique for packing instruction determination (condition tables/access sequences/records) using only the fields SAP exposes in the field catalog

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/758cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/e78cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html

2. You can sent to SAP request/incident to have Production Version added to the determination field catalog or to have a suitable Cloud Badi released on Customer Influence: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Article Discontinuation
entry.content:
Article Discontinuation – Business and Technical Overview

Article Discontinuation is a key step in an article’s lifecycle when the business decides that the product should no longer be carried. This decision can stem from several business scenarios, including:

Business Reasons for Article Discontinuation

  • Seasonal Fashion Items: Style cycles end and new season assortments are introduced.
  • End-of-Life Packaging Changes: Example: shifting from plastic bottles to eco-friendly recyclable packaging.
  • Model Upgrades in Electronics: Regular product refresh cycles.
  • Poor Sales Performance: Example: a slow-moving cereal brand removed by a grocery retailer.
  • Vendor Stops Supplying the Product.
  • Regulatory or Compliance Restrictions.
  • Short Shelf-Life or Expiry Constraints.
  • Assortment Rationalization / Space Optimization.
  • Product Safety Recalls.

Additionally, there are cases where an article is initially listed broadly for simplicity, but this creates technical issues later. In SAP Retail, listing is driven by general assortments, assortment modules, and listing conditions, and articles should only appear in sites belonging to their intended assortments. Incorrect assignments can cause unwanted listing propagation.

Business Impact of Incorrect Listing

  • Inaccurate stock availability displayed to store teams and online channels.
  • Unnecessary MRP proposals generated for all sites.
  • Incorrect data distributed to POS systems, causing clutter and possible cashier confusion.
  • Merchandising teams receive inaccurate assortment compliance reports.

Technical Impact

  • Unintended listing entries created in WLK1.
  • Additional footprints generated in tables such as MVKE, MARC, MBEW, etc.
  • POS outbound IDocs (WP_PLU) triggered for all sites.
  • Increased load on replenishment processing and EDI queues.
  • Incorrect inherited listing indicators in WRS1.
  • Business processes such as costing process unnecessary data, potentially affecting performance and increasing system footprint.

 Delisting vs. Discontinuation

Delisting (Removing Listing Conditions)

Delisting stops an article from being processed but does not remove the article master footprint.

Transaction codes for delisting:

  • WSP3 – Delete individual article listing conditions per distribution chain
  • WSE6 – Delete listing per assortment
  • Removing a site from an assortment using WSOA6 automatically delists all articles belonging to that site/assortment combination.

System behavior when an article is delisted:

  • Listing conditions are deleted automatically.
  • All listing entries (WLK1, WRS1, etc.) created through that assortment/module are removed.
  • The article master remains intact (MARA, MARC, MARD not deleted).
  • Existing stock remains visible and sellable.
  • MRP and procurement are blocked—no new POs/STOs will be created.
  • Sales may continue until on-hand stock reaches zero.

Article Discontinuation (Removing the Article Footprint)

To eliminate an article from the system, the process involves:

  1. Discontinuation – Sets the deletion indicator (LVORM)
  2. Archiving and Deletion – Executed via SARA (Object: MM_MATNR)

Discontinuation has far greater impact than delisting. When an article is discontinued:

  • The article master and all related data (purchasing info records, listing data, etc.) are marked for removal and eventually deleted through archiving.

Levels of Discontinuation

  • Client-wide
  • Supplier/Vendor
  • Plant/Site (includes distribution chain level)

Article Discontinuation Process in SAP Retail

  1. End listing conditions for the article using WSP3/WSE6/WSOA6.
  2. Trigger discontinuation using WRF_DIS_SEL (and monitor via WRF_DIS_MON).
  3. The discontinuation runs based on the Article Discontinuation Date—this must be after the ordering or sales block date.
  4. To run in background:
    • Deselect “Check material in full”
    • Select “Offline checks”

  1. Review the worklist in WRF_DIS_MON after job completion.
  2. If “Discontinue Immediately” is enabled and checks pass, SAP sets the deletion flag automatically.
  3. If issues exist, SAP lists them for manual resolution.
  4. Optional automated follow-up actions (e.g., transfer posting stock to a value-only article).
  5. Configuration: SPRO → Logistics General → Material Master → Retail Specific Settings → Settings for Material Discontinuation
  6. Once LVORM is set → Archive and delete via SARA (MM_MATNR).

Useful Information & Tools

Set deletion flags at Sales Org/Distribution Channel level

Use standard report RWSORT41MVKE
Key fields:

  • AUF_SAM: Explode generic material
  • P_TEST: Test mode
  • S_MATKL: Article Group
  • S_MATNR: Article
  • S_VKORG: Sales Organization
  • S_VTWEG: Distribution Channel

Mass Discontinuation for All Articles at a Site

  • Enter wildcard (*) for article in WRF_DIS_SEL
  • Enter target plant/site under Plant Data
  • Note: This selects all MARC records for that site—evaluate volume before execution.

Reset Deletion Flag

Use WSE8

Important Limitations

  • Discontinuation indicators in MARA/MARC cannot be set using BAPIs or IDocs. Only WRF_DIS_SEL supports this process.

entry.title: Recap SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025
entry.content:
SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025: A Celebration of Community, Innovation, and Shared Knowledge.
What a journey it's been! Last November 14th, we wrapped up the 9th edition of SAP Inside Track Barcelona, and I'm still buzzing from the energy, connections, and incredible moments we shared together.

More Than Just an Event

There's something truly special about SAP Inside Track. Yes, it's about SAP technologies, innovation, and learning — but at its core, it's about people. It's about creating a space where developers, consultants, architects, and SAP enthusiasts can come together, share their experiences, and build genuine connections that go beyond the professional realm.
This year, we brought together +100 passionate individuals in a historic Modernist building in the heart of Barcelona. From the moment the doors opened until the last photo was taken the spirit of community was palpable.


Knowledge That Inspires

The quality of sessions this year was outstanding. Our speakers delivered thought-provoking presentations covering the full spectrum of SAP technologies:

  • AI and Innovation: From Vision AI applications in quality management to conversational AI solutions that let you "talk" to your data
  • SAP BTP: Deep dives into the Business Technology Platform and its transformative capabilities of SAP Hana with Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph
  • Next-Generation Talent: Insights into how SAP University Alliances is empowering the future of our ecosystem
  • SAP BTP Real-World Solutions: Practical implementations of SAP Integration Suite, CAP, FIORI, Printing solution, Identity Services, sand more
  • Freelance market barometer 2025

A special highlight was the Spanish final of the AUSIA Hackathon -  AUSAPE final,  where we witnessed incredible creativity and problem-solving. Congratulations to SDG Group for their winning solution combining AI, data modeling, and planning on SAP BTP, and to Brait Partners for their innovative electronic invoicing automation platform. Both teams proved that new technologies have real, tangible applications in today's business landscape.

The Power of Community: A New Milestone

Speaking of community strength, I'm thrilled to share some exciting news that perfectly exemplifies what we've built together: three new extraordinary members from our community have just joined the SAP Champions program! This recognition is a testament to the collaborative spirit, knowledge sharing, and genuine passion that defines our Barcelona and Spain SAP ecosystem. It's proof that when we come together, support each other, and actively contribute to the community, incredible things happen. These achievements don't belong to individuals alone — they're a reflection of the nurturing environment we've created through events like SIT Barcelona. Congratulations to our new Champions; you make us all proud! 🏆 @AAncos @DanielMateo @Lluis 


Gratitude to Those Who Made It Possible

None of this would have been possible without our amazing volunteering speakers who shared their expertise, experiences, and passion. Your willingness to prepare, present, and engage with attendees is what makes SIT Barcelona such a valuable learning experience. Thank you for your time, your knowledge, and your commitment to our community.
To our sponsors — thank you for believing in the power of community events. Your support enables us to create these spaces where innovation flourishes and connections are made. You're not just supporting an event; you're investing in the growth and development of the SAP ecosystem in Spain.

And I must give a huge, heartfelt thank you to the entire SIT Barcelona organizing team, Lluís, Mireia, Enric, Losel, Imma and Saul. Your dedication, countless hours of planning, problem-solving on the fly, and unwavering passion made this 9th edition possible. You are the backbone of this community, and working alongside each of you has been an absolute privilege💙

The Heart of It All: Community

What sets SAP Inside Track apart from other tech events is the genuine sense of community we've built together over these nine years. It's in the coffee conversations, the spontaneous debates about architecture patterns, the exchange of LinkedIn profiles, and yes, even in the collective patience when life happens (like dog medication time!).
I've seen friendships form, collaborations spark, and careers transform through the connections made at SIT Barcelona. Whether you're a first-time attendee or a veteran of all nine editions, everyone is welcomed with open arms into this wonderful ecosystem we've created together.

Looking Ahead

As we celebrate the success of our 9th edition, we're already excited about what's to come. The 10th anniversary of SIT Barcelona is on the horizon, and we have a feeling it's going to be something truly special.
To everyone who attended, spoke, sponsored, organized, or simply spread the word — thank you. You are the reason SAP Inside Track Barcelona exists and thrives. You are the community.
Until next year, keep innovating, keep sharing, and keep being awesome! 🚀

P.S. — If you missed this edition or want to be part of this amazing community, stay tuned for announcements about SIT Barcelona 2026. Trust me, you don't want to miss the 10th anniversary!
#SITBarcelona #SAPInsideTrack #SAPCommunity #SAP #SAPBTP #SAPDevelopers #CommunityEvents #BarcelonaTech #TechCommunity

entry.title: Re: Is the matrix relationship to the job relationship required?

Since your goal is to use them in workflow approver steps and not for employee profile visibility, the position-level setup alone will work. entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can copy into their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP RDP has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, grouping all paper-related fractions) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with an extensive rule library that offers a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users’ reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country’s EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP RDP community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user’s requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP RDP Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

“Only 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.” (from consumer products company)

“First we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.” (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What’s Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.

entry.title: Re: How to Call RAP Actions with Table Types from a List Report
entry.content:
@akhileshvatupalli123464 

My example already requires frontend code. If you are asking about "opening a popup" without the need to define fragments etc., yes, it is possible with the EditFlow's invokeAction method. Instead of using ContextBinding's execute method, invokeAction integrates with the Extension API and opens a popup if parameters are required for the action.

An alternative would be to define an action that takes a single entity and returns a single result, and set the invocation grouping to "change set". This way, all the selected rows will be passed to the event handler and can be processed in one go. 

Action Definition

action actionname parameter zabs_input result [1] zabs_output;

Annotation

 @UI.lineItem: [
  {
    label: 'Activate',
    dataAction: 'myAction',
    invocationGrouping: #CHANGE_SET,
    type: #FOR_ACTION,
    position: 1 
  }
]

entry.title: CAP Java Draft: Read-Only Field Not Persisted to Active Entity on Activation
entry.content:
Hi community,

I’m working with CAP Java and trying to implement soft deletion for items removed from the Object Page table.
When a user deletes an item (Composition Child) in edit mode, I mark the item as logically deleted by setting isDeleted = true.
I achieved this by setting the flag in the @On DraftService.EVENT_DRAFT_CANCEL event handler.

However, when the isDeleted field is annotated with @readonly, @Core.Immutable, or @Common.FieldControl: #ReadOnly, the flag is not transferred to the active entity when the draft is activated.
This issue occurs only in CAP Java — the same logic works correctly in CAP Node.js.

I’ve created a minimal reproducible example on GitHub:

https://github.com/miyasuta/cap-java-draft-composition-delete

Has anyone experienced similar behavior or knows whether this is a known limitation of CAP Java drafts?

entry.title: Skills Architecture Playbook: 10 Design Decisions with Talent Intelligence Hub that Define Success !
entry.content:
The shift towards a skills-based workforce is picking up speed, and this transformation lives or dies on one thing: your skills architecture, the foundation that defines:

  • how skills are structured,
  • how they are governed,
  • how they flow through your HRtech landscape, and
  • how employees, managers, and admins actually experience them.

What’s happening -
Most organizations jump straight into “skills projects” without stopping to define the design decisions that truly matter! I have seen SAP SuccessFactors customers engaging with different HRTech or Skills vendors separately, rather than as a coherent group. The result? Duplicate skills across systems, messy job profiles, confused employees, frustrated managers, and governance models held together with duct tape.

Think of this blog as your Skills Architecture Playbook: the 10 decisions every company must get right to build a clean, future-proof foundation with Talent Intelligence Hub. These decisions will shape everything from AI models and inference reliability to employee growth journeys and manager adoption.

If you’re implementing TIH, planning a Skills Transformation, or just trying to bring order to the skills chaos, this guide is for you.

Let’s get into the decisions that define your success.

Leading Practice Skills Architecture with Talent Intelligence Hub

Here’s a leading practice approach for designing a Skills Architecture with TIH at its core. Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners help augment and complement customers' internal data, creating a high-quality skills foundation that brings together market skills data, job and work insights, and people attributes.

Once standardized in Talent Intelligence Hub and enriched with employee and organizational master data from SuccessFactors, this unified skills intelligence can be delivered through Career and Talent Development (CTD) as the experience layer for every persona -employees, managers, HR, recruiters, and leaders.

I had shared this diagram in my session at SuccessConnect and have further explained it in my podcast. Give it a listen -  Art of the Possible - Episode 1 - Skills-based Transformation - Talent Alchemy Podcast series

This is how you bring a skills-based transformation concept to life.

1. Choose Your System of Record: Where Does Job & Skills Truth Live?

Everything starts with a single question: Where does the truth sit? 

For job architecture and skills governance, SAP SuccessFactors Talent Intelligence Hub should be your system of record and governance layer.

Here’s how it breaks down:

TIH + JPB = Your Master Foundation

  • Job Families
  • Job Roles
  • Job Profiles
  • Skills Library
  • Skills tagged to roles and profiles
  1. JPB holds your job architecture. 
  2. Open Skills Ecosystem partners enrich your skills library.
  3. TIH governs and standardizes everything.

Get this foundation right, and the rest of your skills strategy becomes infinitely easier.

2. Standardize Skills in the Attributes Library with AI Skills Standardization

Once you know where the truth lives, the next step is: What does that truth look like? The Attributes Library in TIH is your governance layer for all skills master data.

It helps you:

  • Maintain a clean, unified skills library.
  • Standardizes the Skills data into one common language. 
  • Manage lifecycle states (active, deprecated, standardized)
  • Standardize proficiency scales

Your Open Skills Ecosystem partner sends business- and industry-relevant skill data into TIH, where you standardize it.

This avoids:

  • Duplicate skills
  • Confusing naming conventions
  • Skill inflation
  • Random “HR-created” one-off skills

This is your quality control engine.

Check out my Talent Alchemy Bits and Bytes segment, where I talked about Skills Standardization. 

3. Decide How Skills Will Be Validated

If there’s one thing employees love, it’s adding skills. If there’s one thing managers love… It’s being skeptical of those skills. Validation matters!

You need to decide: 

Who validates the skills?

  • Employee?
  • Manager?
  • Both?
  • Or does it depend on the skill type?

What’s the sequence?

  • Employee declares → Manager approves
  • Manager nominates → Employee confirms
  • System infers → Employee validates → Manager approves

Consistency is key.

Which system is the system of record for validation?

TIH/Growth Portfolio or your OSE partner?

Either works—just don’t let both do it independently. That’s how data chaos is born.

4. Define Your Skills Signals Strategy

Skills come from everywhere. Projects, learning, bots, assessments… even legacy tools that are somehow still alive. Your rule of survival:  SAP SuccessFactors Growth Portfolio should be the master system of record for all employee skill interactions.

That means:

  • Employees view and update skills here
  • Managers make decisions here
  • HR governs here
  • Partners feed into here

Other systems can contribute, but they can’t own the truth

5. Choose What Skills You will Infer and from Where?

Skill inferencing is magical… unless it pulls the wrong signals. You need to define:

What external sources can infer skills?

  • Project systems
  • Legacy HR/LMS tools
  • External learning platforms
  • Gig/mobility platforms
  • Assessment vendors

How will you judge quality?

Set thresholds such as:

  • Evidence required
  • Confidence level
  • Relevance to job or industry
  • Duplication rules

Which SF processes continuously infer skills?

  • Learning completions
  • Internal gigs
  • Performance achievements
  • Career development activities

A thoughtful inferencing strategy prevents “noise skills” and keeps your profiles trustworthy.

6. Decide Where Employee Skills Data Should Flow

Once an employee’s skills are updated and validated, where does that data go?

Typical downstream consumers include:

  • Recruiting
  • Learning
  • Opportunity Marketplace
  • Workforce planning
  • Career & succession tools
  • Assessment vendors
Important: "If you have multiple skills-enabled vendors (LMS, recruiting, assessment tools), Growth Portfolio remains the master. Application partners consume standardized data; they don’t manage it. This keeps your ecosystem clean and consistent."

7. Define How the Skills Taxonomy Will Be Propagated

Your skills taxonomy flows outward from TIH into the rest of the ecosystem.

TIH is your:

  • Skills system of record
  • Job architecture governance tool
  • Standardization engine
  • Master metadata source

If you use multiple Open Skills Ecosystem (OSE) partners:

Pick ONE to be your skills architecture provider. Why?

Because multiple skills dictionaries = chaos.
One dictionary + TIH governance = sanity.

8. Design the Employee Experience (Growth Portfolio and..)

Employees are the heart of your skills ecosystem. Decide:

How much ownership do they have?

  • Full self-declaration
  • Only inferred skills
  • Only validated skills
  • Only view or able to manage skills
  • A blended model

What should they see?

  • Validated skills
  • Inferred skills
  • Critical or core skills
  • Skill gaps

How guided should their experience be?

  • Single entry inside SuccessFactors
  • Some interactions inside partner tools
  • Or a completely unified Growth Portfolio experience

The goal?
Keep it simple, intuitive, and aligned to growth, not admin work.

9. Design the Manager Experience (Teams View and...)

Managers are where skills turn into results, development, mobility, and readiness. You need to define:

How much oversight managers have: Do they validate? Approve? Only for critical skills?

How deeply do skills feed talent decisions

Should they use skills to:

  • Recommend learning
  • Suggest gigs
  • Nominate for roles
  • Support succession plans
  • Plan team capabilities

What feedback loops they own

After:

  • Projects
  • Assignments
  • Reskilling initiatives

Manager feedback becomes key evidence for skill proficiency.

10. Design the Admin Experience (Governance, Analytics, and ...)

Admins run the heartbeat of your skills ecosystem. Define:

Who owns the skills library?

  • HR COE?
  • Talent?
  • Learning?
  • A cross-functional governance team?

How partners integrate

External vendors must feed into Growth Portfolio without duplicating or reinventing your skills.

What KPIs HR will track

Some examples:

  • % validated critical skills
  • Internal fill rate
  • Mobility rate
  • Skills coverage vs. demand
  • Time-to-proficiency
  • Learning-to-skills conversion

Conclusion: Your Skills Architecture Is Your Future

Building a skills-based organization is not about collecting skills, it’s about creating a system of truth, a system of intelligence, and most importantly, a system of experience that employees and managers trust.

  • Talent Intelligence Hub gives you the governance layer.
  • Growth Portfolio with CTD (Career & Talent Development solution) provides the experience layer.
  • Your open ecosystem partners give you the enrichment layer.

But your design decisions tie it all together.

Get these decisions right, and skills become the engine behind: talent mobility, workforce agility, learning personalization, internal career growth, and more. Get them wrong, and you’ll spend months reconciling data, chasing inconsistencies, and wondering why adoption is low.

With Talent Intelligence Hub at the center and these 10 decisions guiding your journey, you can build not only an architecture, but a future-ready, human-centered skills ecosystem that actually works.

entry.title: Re: BSX Account Transaction After applying SAP Note 1677806
entry.content:
Hi @Gomez 
The issue you’re seeing (BSX posting alongside TXO after applying SAP Note 1677806) is a known side effect when the posting string WA04 is not fully aligned with the BAdI implementation. The note specifies that only TXO should be triggered, but if BSX is still appearing, it usually means the posting string or account determination logic is incomplete or misapplied in your S/4HANA 2023 environment. To resolve this you have to do following as mentioned below.

1. Check Posting String WA04
Ensure WA04 is correctly assigned in the BAdI implementation as per the SAP Note. WA04 should explicitly exclude BSX and only trigger TXO.

2. Validate OBYC Settings
In transaction OBYC, review the BSX and TXO account determination. Confirm that BSX is not linked to movement type 541 after the note implementation.

3. Debug the BAdI Execution
Run a test posting with movement 541 and debug the BAdI logic. Verify whether WA04 is being called and whether BSX is being added by fallback logic.

4. Raise an OSS Incident
Since you’re on S/4HANA Private 2023, this may be a regression or adaptation gap. SAP Support can provide a correction transport or updated note for your release.

Hope this will help you

entry.title: Re: S4H: Print Freight Condition Total Value after Revisi...
entry.content:
Hello @TaniaTrindade 

what i understand purchasing/print form issue where the freight condition (header-level condition) is being recalculated or displayed incorrectly after partial GR and PO revision. My suggestion for you to do the following as mentioned below.

1. Print from Header Condition Directly
Adjust the PO print form (SmartForm / Adobe Form) logic to read the freight condition value from the header (EKPO/EKKO + KONV) instead of summing item-level distributed values. This way, the printout always shows the full freight cost (500 USD), regardless of GR status.

2. Use Condition Value (KONV)
In KONV, freight condition (e.g., FRB1, HD00, or custom Z-condition) is stored with header indicator. Fetch the KWERT (condition value) for the freight condition at header level. Ensure the print program doesn’t filter by open items only.

3. Custom Logic in Print Program
Enhance the PO output program (usually MEDRUCK or custom ZMEDRUCK) to, check if the condition is header-level. Print the total value (500 USD) instead of the distributed item values. This avoids dependency on GR status.

4. Alternative: Display Both
Some clients prefer showing, Total freight (header) = 500 USD then Remaining freight (open items) = 100 USD. This can be achieved by printing both header condition and distributed item condition values.

Identify the freight condition type in your system (check PO conditions tab). In the print form logic, if condition is header-level → print KONV-KWERT directly.
If condition is item-level → sum across items.
Test with revised PO where GR is partial to confirm.

Let me know if you need more clarity.

entry.title: @cap-js/mcp-server - Practical guide to get value on day on
entry.content:
Give your coding assistant instant, project‑aware knowledge of your CAP model and docs. With @cap-js/mcp-server, the assistant can look up entities, services, fields, and HTTP endpoints from your compiled CDS model and cross‑check official CAP docs, so it proposes the right code and changes in your editor.

Here's where I found this and would like to share with community - https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

  • Package: @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Command: cds-mcp
  • Tools: search_model (compiled CDS/CSN), search_docs (local CAP docs embeddings)
  • Works with MCP‑capable assistants in VS Code and other IDEs (e.g., Cline, Copilot Agent Mode, opencode)

Here’s the short version - just follow these 3 step

  1. Configure your IDE agent to start the server via npx:
{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}
  1. Add these rules to AGENTS.md so the assistant always uses the server correctly:
- You MUST search for CDS definitions, like entities, fields and services (which include HTTP endpoints) with cds-mcp, only if it fails you MAY read *.cds files in the project.
- You MUST search for CAP docs with cds-mcp EVERY TIME you create, modify CDS models or when using APIs or the `cds` CLI from CAP. Do NOT propose, suggest or make any changes without first checking it.
  1. Optional CLI smoke test:
npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Why you’ll love it

  • Stop guessing: Fuzzy‑search your compiled model for entities, services, elements, annotations, and endpoints.
  • Fewer mistakes: Suggestions are grounded in your actual model and verified against official CAP docs.
  • All local: Fast and private, perfect for day‑to‑day development.

IDE setup

VS Code - Cline extension

Settings example:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {}
    }
  }
}

VS Code - GitHub Copilot Agent Mode (global mcp.json)

{
  "servers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "env": {},
      "type": "stdio"
    },
    "inputs": []
  }
}

opencode

{
  "mcp": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "type": "local",
      "command": ["npx", "-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
      "enabled": true
    }
  }
}

Tip: Keep the server name “cds-mcp” in both your config and prompts so your assistant reliably calls it.

How to use it in your editor

Think “discover first, then change.” Ask your assistant to:

  • Discover model and endpoints

    • “Use cds‑mcp search_model to list all services and their HTTP endpoints. Then list entities with primary keys.”

  • Write a correct SELECT with expand

    • “Call cds‑mcp search_model for Books and its associations. Then, after checking CAP Node.js SELECT expand syntax via cds‑mcp search_docs, propose a handler that returns Books.title, Books.stock and expands auther.name.”

  • Generate precise OData URLs

    • “Find the service and endpoint for Books via search_model, then give me an OData V4 URL with $select=title,stock and $expand=author($select=name) plus a curl example.”

  • Safely change CDS/annotations

    • “Show docs for @Common.Label using cds‑mcp search_docs. Using search_model for Books, propose a minimal diff adding labels for title and stock. Include file paths.”

  • Plan a refactor

    • “We’re renaming Author to Writer. With cds‑mcp search_model, list affected entities, associations, services, and endpoints; propose a step‑by‑step PR plan.”

  • Implement an action/handler

    • “Find docs on defining and implementing a custom action in Node.js via cds‑mcp search_docs. Then sketch a minimal handler in srv/<service>.js with imports and input validation.”

Best practice: Ask the assistant to paste the search_model and search_docs results that justify any change.

CLI usage (optional but handy)

Install globally to test from your terminal:

npm i -g @cap-js/mcp-server
  • Search your compiled model:
cds-mcp search_model . Books entity
  • Search CAP documentation:
cds-mcp search_docs "how to add columns to a select statement in CAP Node.js" 1

Once the CLI works, your IDE agent can invoke the same tools automatically.

What the tools return

  • search_model

    • Names and kinds (entity, service, etc.)
    • Elements and annotations
    • File locations
    • HTTP endpoints where services are exposed

  • search_docs

    • The most relevant CAP documentation snippets for your query, based on local embeddings

Use both together: discover exact names/paths with search_model, confirm syntax and best practices with search_docs, then apply small, reviewable changes.

Tips for getting the most value

  • Start every task with search_model to avoid typos and stale assumptions.
  • Require docs‑backed edits: have the assistant run search_docs before proposing code.
  • Keep edits atomic: one focused change at a time, with file paths and minimal diffs.
  • Monorepo? Tell the assistant the CAP project folder to search.

Support and contribution

  • Issues and feature requests: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/issues
  • Security policy: https://github.com/cap-js/mcp-server/security/policy
  • Code of Conduct: https://github.com/cap-js/.github/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md
  • License and REUSE info: see LICENSE and https://api.reuse.software/info/github.com/cap-js/mcp-server

Now action - 

  • Add the MCP config, paste the two rules into AGENTS.md, and ask your assistant:
    “Discover all entities, keys, and endpoints with cds‑mcp search_model, verify the Node.js SELECT docs with cds‑mcp search_docs, then propose a minimal handler change for Books.”

    SAP Business Technology Platform  SAP Business AI SAP Cloud Application Programming Model

entry.title: 新しい認定試験方式受けてみた
entry.content:
はじめに

先日アナウンスがあったとおり、SAPの認定試験が、これまでの選択式の試験からより実践的な試験に変更になるようです。
https://community.sap.com/t5/sap-learning-blog-posts/reimagining-certification-for-the-way-we-work-today/ba-p/14261141

現時点では一部の試験だけですが「2026年までに 、 すべてのSAP認定資格がこの新しい実践的な形式に移行します。」と記載されています。

  • 実技試験には2種類あるってことだけど、システム・ベース、シナリオ・ベースそれぞれどんな感じなの？
  • 英語で対応する必要がある？
  • オープンブック形式ってことだけど監督は全然されないってこと？

などが気になりつつ、さっそくチャレンジしてきました。

この記事は SAPアドベントカレンダー 2025 の 12月1日分の記事として執筆しています。

共通すること

  • 予約は不要になりました。いつでも好きなタイミングで受験できます。試験の監督官はつきません。
  • システムベースかシナリオベースかは、試験ごとにあらかじめ決まっています。おそらく、開発系の試験はシステムベース、アプリ系の試験はシナリオベースになるのだと思います。
  • このページをちゃんと読むと書いてありますが、Start Certification Examを押してから24hのカウントがあり、そのあとのステップに進むボタンを押してから2h（試験によっては3h）以内に終了する必要があります。システムベースだと、Access Practice Examをクリックしたタイミング、シナリオベースの場合、AIとのロールプレイにするかビデオ提出にするかを選択したタイミングです。
  • 各試験の案内ページのPrepare for Certification から行ける Learning Journey がためになるので、試験受けるか迷っていても、のぞいてみるのをおすすめします。たぶん、Learning Hub 持っていなくてもアクセスできます（ものによるのかも）

システム・ベース受けてみた（SAP Generative AI Developer）

1か月の無料トライアルを申し込んだときと同じような、IDのすでに決まった環境が割り当てられます。手順PDFがダウンロードできるので、その指示に従って環境に設定を行っていきます。

  • PDFは英語ですが、オープンブック形式ということは翻訳手段は何とでもなるのでハードルにはならないかと思います。
  • 各ステップの完了目安時間が示されているので、時間配分に気を付けながら進めていく必要があります。
  • Learning Journey の Practical Exercise を理解していれば、問題なく進められる内容でした。

シナリオ・ベース受けてみた（SAP Business Data Cloud）

スタートすると、「Yoodliを始める」というボタンとともに、カメラとマイクをONにしろ、と言われてビビりますが、回答内容を認識するためのものなので気楽にONにしてください。SAP Business Data Cloud の導入を検討しているユーザによる面接という体で、様々な質問をされるので、それに回答していきます。

  • AI、日本語で話してくれます！ので、もちろん日本語で答えれば大丈夫です。
  • 途中で通信状態が悪かったのか画面が固まってしまい進めずに焦りましたが、リロードしたら問題なく最初からやり直しになりました。（Don’t close this page と表示されていたのでビクビクしながら更新しましたが大丈夫でした）
  • オープンブック形式ということで、質問されてから色々見て回答を探しながら回答できます。そうすると、質問されてからかなり沈黙の時間が流れてしまいますが、そこは問題なさそうでした。ちゃんと回答を話し出すまで待ってくれます。
  • AIからの質問が終わると、スコアが表示されます。分野ごとに、どれくらいのレベルで回答できていたかが示されます。
  • このときに、AIの質問と自分の回答の文字起こしも表示されるので「文字起こしをコピー」ボタンでコピーしてどこかに保存することができます
  • 最初のスコアで合格ラインを越えられなかったのですが、時間内であれば最初からやり直すことができ、試験回数を追加で消費せずに合格することができました

おわりに

監督する人との会話がなく、部屋を見せる必要も身分証明書を出す必要もない試験、気楽でした！

試験の難易度的にも、かなり楽になってしまったのではないかと感じました。ここはこのまま行って大丈夫なのか、疑問が残ります。と言ってもシナリオベースで頑張ったつもりで67％のスコアしか取れなかったので、その領域についての知識の地図が頭にできてないと、厳しそうです。

以前の選択式のテストも、認定取ったからってその領域のコンサルとして明日から働けるか？はわからなかったわけで、「この実践テストを乗り越えたということは、何かを参照にしながらなら問題解決できますね」という方が目的にかなっているということなのかもしれません。

entry.title: Re: Serial Number Profile : Prefix (CBC activity 103636)
entry.content:
Hello @adrien_delanoe

The serialisation procedure you see in the WM view has nothing to do with the serial number prefix from SSCUI 103636, the serial number profile used in your inventory management, or equipment master serial number ranges. These are two different frameworks.

To answer your question, the serialisation procedure is used to defined whether EWM should enforce serialisation, at which step your system captures the serial numbers, whether thy are managed at storage bin level/stock level or for duplicate validation. This basically means that this field only controls your operational behaviour but not the number ranges.

However, the serial number profile SSCUI 103636 is the only part that affects the number created. Which also addresses what I clarified in my earlier answer. Meaning it only applies when you use EWM serialisation and not Inventory Management.

My initial guidance steps were focused on showing that the prefix only works inside EWM serialisation, the need to activate it for your material to be extended and to inform you that without it, your system will not use the warehouse serialisation setting, leading to prefix not appearing.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: RF Device printing issue -SAP WM Public Cloud 2508
entry.content:
Good day @SaleemSk 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

HU Shipping Label, Sources of Condition Parameters Used in Output Parameter Determination, Integration of Handling Units, SCM-EWM-PRN - Printing, Overview of Handling Units.

In summary, the current public cloud release does not enable the F1 Pack function to trigger HU label output. That is the reason why your system does not create the print queue when you press F1 pack, even though HU label printing works from the packing work center and the warehouse monitor.

In public cloud, HU label printing in these apps is not driven by the output parameter determination app. The system does not expose HU label output types there and there is no configuration or BAdI that allows you to automatically call HU label printing.

Due to public cloud’s clean-core restrictions, you may either print HU labels from the packing work center or warehouse monitor after your packing or you use RF printing transaction and trigger printing through the RF print function key and not through the F1 Pack.

Also considering the public cloud's clean-core principle restricts RF transaction modification, should you require automatic printing directly from F1 pack, you can only achieve that through an external or BTP-based extension.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition: A New Generation of Global Tax Compliance
entry.content:
In a world where governments are rapidly digitizing tax controls, companies must ensure real-time reporting, accurate e-invoicing, and seamless integration with local authorities. SAP has long supported these needs through its Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) solution embedded in SAP S/4HANA.

As regulatory demands increase and cloud adoption accelerates, SAP introduced Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition—a next-generation, cloud-native platform designed to help enterprises respond faster, comply globally, and scale efficiently.

This article explains both solutions and highlights the key differences that set the Cloud Edition apart.

 

What Is SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)?

DRC is the integrated compliance framework within SAP S/4HANA, built to support:

  • Electronic invoicing (eDocuments)

  • Legal reporting (SAF-T, VAT, Intrastat, etc.)

  • Indirect tax submissions

  • Real-time government integrations

  • Audit and compliance workflows

DRC leverages SAP S/4HANA’s core capabilities, using:

  • Embedded data models

  • Fiori apps

  • Integration with finance and logistics

  • Local add-ons for country-specific mandates

It is ideal for companies that run S/4HANA (on-premise, private cloud or public cloud) and want compliance deeply integrated into transactional flows.

What Is Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition?

DRC Cloud Edition is SAP’s standalone, cloud-native compliance platform built on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

It is designed to:

  • Support global e-invoicing mandates

  • Manage content-rich regulatory reporting

  • Centralize compliance across multiple ERP systems

  • Provide API-based connections to government platforms

  • Deliver continuous updates through the cloud

Unlike DRC embedded in S/4HANA, the Cloud Edition does not depend on the ERP release cycle, allowing SAP to push compliance updates faster and support new regulations more rapidly.

Key Differentiators: DRC vs. DRC Cloud Edition

Below are the main areas where the Cloud Edition differentiates itself from the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA.

1. Deployment Architecture

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
LocationRuns inside SAP S/4HANARuns outside ERP, on SAP BTP
DependenciesTied to ERP version & upgradesIndependent of ERP release cycle
UpdatesDelivered with S/4HANA feature packsContinuous cloud updates

Benefit: Faster adoption of new regulatory requirements with minimal impact on the ERP.

2. Multi-ERP and Non-SAP Integration

Aspect DRC DRC Cloud Edition
Supported systemsPrimarily SAP S/4HANAMulti-ERP, multi-system, including non-SAP
ConsolidationUsually per ERP instanceCentralized compliance hub

Benefit: Ideal for companies with multiple ERPs, global rollouts, or hybrid landscapes.

3. Scalability and Global Coverage

  • DRC Cloud Edition can scale more easily across countries.

  • SAP delivers regulatory content globally through cloud content packages.

  • Government API connectivity is managed centrally.

Benefit: Enterprises expand into new jurisdictions without large ERP projects.

4. Government Integrations and Connectivity

DRC Cloud Edition offers:

  • Managed API gateways to tax authorities

  • Continuous monitoring of government system changes

  • Central message tracking across countries

Benefit: Reduces IT workload and ensures higher resilience for e-invoicing and e-reporting.

5. Innovation, AI and Extensibility

Because it sits on SAP BTP, DRC Cloud Edition can leverage:

  • AI-driven anomaly detection

  • Intelligent validation of documents

  • Faster extensibility via low-code tools

  • Cloud automation services

Benefit: More innovation potential compared to the ERP-embedded DRC.

6. Upgrade Effort and Maintenance

Aspect DRC (Embedded) DRC Cloud Edition
Customer effortMust test with ERP upgradesMinimal customer testing
UpdatesPeriodicContinuous and automatic
MaintenanceShared between ERP team and tax complianceFully handled in the cloud

Benefit: Lower TCO and faster compliance readiness.

When to Choose Each Solution?

Choose DRC (Embedded in S/4HANA) if:

  • You want compliance tightly integrated into transactional finance and logistics.

  • You prefer a single solution inside S/4HANA.

  • You operate primarily in countries already supported within DRC.

Choose DRC Cloud Edition if:

  • You need global multi-country e-invoicing with fast deployment.

  • You operate multiple ERPs or hybrid landscapes.

  • You want rapid response to changing government mandates.

  • You need a future-proof cloud strategy with continuous innovation.

Conclusion

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance Cloud Edition represents the evolution of digital tax compliance—faster, more scalable, and designed for a global, multi-system world.

While the traditional DRC embedded in S/4HANA remains a strong and deeply integrated option, the Cloud Edition expands capabilities with:

  • Cloud-native architecture

  • Faster regulatory updates

  • Centralized global management

  • Support for multiple ERPs

  • Continuous innovation via SAP BTP

Together, both solutions equip organizations to meet today’s regulatory environment and future-proof their compliance landscape.

entry.title: ¿Qué es IFRS 18? Explicación e Impacto para Clientes de SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
IFRS 18 redefine cómo se presentan resultados; en SAP S/4HANA implica reestructurar reportes, cuentas y subtotales para lograr transparencia, comparabilidad y cumplimiento global.

1. ¿Qué es IFRS 18?

IFRS 18 – Presentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements es la nueva norma emitida por IASB que sustituye a IAS 1.
Su objetivo es estandarizar y hacer más comparables los estados financieros entre empresas, mejorando la transparencia y consistencia en:

  • Presentación del estado de resultados

  • Clasificación de gastos

  • Subtotales obligatorios

  • Información por “gestión” (management approach)

  • Notas y revelaciones

Entrará en vigor a partir de 2027 (con adopción anticipada permitida).

2. ¿Qué cambia con IFRS 18? Principales novedades

A) Nuevas categorías obligatorias en el Estado de Resultados

IFRS 18 introduce tres nuevas categorías estandarizadas:

  1. Operating (Operativas)

  2. Investing (Inversiones)

  3. Financing (Financiamiento)

— además de requerir subtotales como Operating Profit.

B) Mayor claridad en gastos por función o por naturaleza

Las empresas deben elegir un solo enfoque principal y justificarlo.
Requiere revelaciones adicionales cuando los gastos se presentan por función.

C) Subtotales estandarizados obligatorios

Incluye métricas que antes eran voluntarias, ahora definidas bajo una guía uniforme.

D) Reglas más estrictas para “Management-defined Performance Measures (MPM)”

Cualquier KPI financiero que la administración use (como EBITDA ajustado, margen recurrente, etc.) debe:

  • Definirse formalmente

  • Explicarse

  • Conciliarse con IFRS

  • Divulgarse consistentemente

E) Cambios en notas y estructura narrativa

Nuevos requerimientos de presentación de información complementaria, con foco en consistencia.

3. Impacto para los clientes que utilizan SAP S/4HANA

1. Ajustes en el modelo de reporting financiero

Se deberán adaptar:

  • Estructuras del P&L

  • Versiones de reporte

  • Hierarquías financieras

  • Indicadores y subtotales

La nueva estructuración se resuelve especialmente con SAP Group Reporting.

2. Cambios en el modelo de cuentas y asignaciones

IFRS 18 exigirá revisar:

  • Clasificación de gastos operativos vs. no operativos

  • Determinación de categorías (operativa, inversión, financiamiento)

  • Cuentas contables y agrupaciones en FS Items

Esto puede requerir ajustes en:

  • Chart of Accounts (COA)

  • FS Item derivation

  • Profit center / Segment assignments

3. Reconfiguración de reportes y KPIs

IFRS 18 exige nuevos subtotales estandarizados como:

  • Operating Profit

  • Profit before Financing and Investing

  • Profit before Income Taxes

En SAP se habilitan mediante:

  • Fiori Analytical Apps

  • SAP Analytics Cloud

  • Group Reporting Data Collection (GRDC)

4. Impacto en empresas que usan CO-PA / Margin Analysis

Se necesitarán:

  • Nuevas derivaciones para categorías operativas/financieras

  • Alineación entre rentabilidad operativa interna y estado de resultados IFRS

Margin Analysis facilitará este alineamiento gracias al Universal Journal.

5. Mayor importancia de SAP Group Reporting

Group Reporting será crítico porque:

  • Permite mapear FS Items a categorías IFRS 18

  • Ajustar subtotales en consolidación

  • Alinear reportes individuales y consolidados

  • Gestionar KPI definidos por la administración (MPMs)

6. Impacto en divulgación y notas financieras

Con IFRS 18, empresas deberán generar notas más estructuradas y reconciliaciones nuevas.
SAP facilitará esto a través de:

  • GRDC (Group Reporting Data Collection)

  • Disclosure Management Tools

  • Plantillas estandarizadas para notas

7. Cambios en SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC)

Para empresas que generen reportes locales a partir de estados IFRS, los cambios en P&L obligan a:

  • Revisar layouts

  • Ajustar reportes regulatorios

  • Sincronizar derivaciones financieras

4. ¿Qué deben hacer los clientes de SAP S/4HANA?

Acciones recomendadas:

1. Evaluación del modelo actual de P&L

Comparar la estructura existente vs. la requerida por IFRS 18.

2. Impact assessment técnico y funcional

Revisar COA, derivaciones, Fiori reports y Group Reporting.

3. Adecuación del reporting consolidado

Mapeo de FS Items → Nuevas categorías IFRS 18.

4. Ajustes en KPIs internos y MPMs

Alinear definiciones con la norma.

5. Actualización de procesos financieros

Cerrar brechas en notas, conciliaciones y subtotales.

entry.title: Re: the CDS of APP Monitor Value Chains
entry.content:
Hi @omega-ou 

Thank you for your question.

In public cloud you cannot use the monitor value chain app to build your report due to the lack of a CDS view that does that. The reason is SAP does not expose value chain engine tables or CDS views in public cloud. The app is based on internal reuse components that are not released for reporting, not visible in View Browser and not extendable through custom CDS.

To build your report, you must join the released analytical cubes yourself.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Mass migration of master data and fixed asset postings
entry.content:
Hello @SFerrand 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not provide any API or BAdI to migrate fixed asset master data or values. The best option is to stick to the migration cockpit and split the load into smaller batches.

I suggest you break the assets into batches of 20-50k assets per run. Then split your postings into multiple files.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
Hi @DianaRoesner 

Honestly, I came away very disappointed with the certification process. It makes me wonder if SAP has ever properly tested the UI.

I had read about the problems others faced — especially with submitting answers — and I tried the BDC certificate hoping those issues wouldn’t happen again. But the trouble started right away.

After accepting the agreement, I had to set up my camera and microphone. I did that, but the “Start” button stayed disabled, saying the camera wasn’t set. Refreshing didn’t help. Strangely, I could still click “Start,” but then I got a shocking error message.

I tried clicking “Restart,” just like it said, but that didn’t fix anything. The same error message popped up again.

I tried “Contact Us,” but instead of SAP support, I landed on a page from yoodli.ai. It just said “How can we help you?” — with no input box at all.  ????!!!!

On their website, the chat told me: “Send us a message, we’ll be back online tomorrow.”   !!!!!!!!

What made it worse was that the exam timer kept ticking down from two hours, even though I couldn’t access the exam at all. It was incredibly frustrating — just sitting there watching the clock run out on something I couldn’t even start. And then, after two hours, the system simply said “Time’s up,” and counted the attempt as failed.

So my questions are:

  • Was this UI ever properly tested before being rolled out?
  • Why hand over such an important exam process to a third-party company?
  • Shouldn’t certification exams be held on working days, when support is available, instead of weekends? Because if not, then the whole idea of ‘anywhere, anytime’ doesn’t make sense anymore.
  • And most importantly: how do I get back my attempt count for a test that never even began?

I’ve already opened a support case with the Learning Support Team, and I really hope they answer quickly — even on the weekend —

entry.title: Re: Clicking “Components Missing” in Manage Production Or...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

  1. Answer to question 1: This often happens if target app could not be found and it therefore returns you to the homepage. Potentially the app is not assigned to your business role.
  2. Answer to question 2: Yes, they are.
  3. Answer to question 3: You need either one of the following roles: SAP_BR_PRODN_PLNR which ensures you have the planner rights in production or SAP_BR_PRODN_SUPERVISOR which gives you the supervisor permission.
  4. Answer to question 4: Yes, it is common in the demo tenants. This is because, in the demo tenants the full catalog are not deployed. Some objects are missing; the missing Parts app and some cross-navigation mappings are either missing or incomplete. As a result, when you click the link, you are routed back to the Launchpad.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Monitor External Requirements – “Too many data record...
entry.content:
Good day @Aght 

Thank you for your question.

To answer your first question, yes it is if your filter function does not cover the required fields.

The system seems to be working as designed. If you miss any critical selection parameter, the backend reads the full MRP dataset and triggers too many records and thereby returns no results. Which then shows no data.

First, I suggest you also filter the Requirement Evaluation Period to limit the search the system carries out. If something is available, the system should generate data.

Alternatively, it could also mean you have no external requirement open for the chosen plants and products. and therefore, no data is generated. I ran the test and the system also provided no data.

What I also did is to run a check on the Monitor Material Coverage APP. As you can see below, the system produced some data showing there are shortages. I suggest you check in this app using the same materials on your screenshot to evaluate if you have some shortages. If you did not find any, then the Alert.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Hide company code by default
entry.content:
Good day @TobiasVoigt 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Configuring Business Roles, Assigning Business Roles to a User, Best Practices for Business Roles, How to Create a Business Role from a Template, Restricting Access Roles, Manage Consolidation Hierarchies

To summarise, the public cloud provides the restriction request through business role restrictions and not through structural configuration. The simplest clean-core way to do what you are intending, is to create one dedicated role that explicitly allows this company code, while all other roles remain without access. Which then means, only users with this special role will see the company code in apps, analytics and value helps. This helps you avoid role duplication.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Copy Text from Sevrice Order to Billing Document
entry.content:
Good day @simon_all4cloud41 

Thank you for your question.

The public cloud does not offer the possibility to transfer service order or service confirmation texts directly into the Billing Document text tabs. You can only do that for SD documents.

Considering the public cloud principle restricts some functionalities, you can only achieve your requirements without custom fields by including the text in the billing output PDF and enabling a service confirmation text through output parameter determination and then map it into the billing form.

However, if your business requirement is to store the text inside the Billing Document itself, you can achieve it only through custom field and custom logic.

Have a look at the following references.

Service Processing Using a Service Order, Service Order Processing,  Service Order - Confirm Processing, Billing Document, Output Determination in the Billing Document

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris
